If you’ve been reading me long enough – or had the misfortune to be trained by me – you’ll probably have heard me describe myself as a “grouchy old cluetrain advocate”. And, by “cluetrain”, I mean [Cluetrain Manifesto](http://cluetrain.com), of course.

(I find the Cluetrain Manifesto to be a useful bozo test – if the “digital expert” or “social media guru” you’re talking to has never heard of it, there’s a fair chance they’re a bozo.)

Well, Cluetrain is *back*.


## New Clues

Two of the original authors of the Manifesto, [Doc Searls](http://blogs.law.harvard.edu/doc/2015/01/08/cluetrain-rides-again/) and [David Weinberger](http://www.hyperorg.com/blogger/2015/01/08/new-clues/), have written [New Clues](http://cluetrain.com/newclues/) – some new clues for today’s internet. And some of it is just biting:

> 60 – Ads that sound human but come from your marketing department’s irritable bowels, stain the fabric of the Web.
> 
>  61 – When personalizing something is creepy, it’s a pretty good indication that you don’t understand what it means to be a person.

It’s well worth taking the time to read in full. And I suspect I’ll be doing “Clues of the day” here for a little while…
